item.title: Continuing Appropriations and Surface Transportation Extensions Act, 2011

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote. (text: CR H8901)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.(text: CR H8901)
The previous question was ordered without objection. (consideration: CR H8905)
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 1782.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H8901-8905)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 259.

The resolution provides for consideration of the Senate amendment to the House amendment to the Senate amendment to H.R. 3082. It provides one hour of debate on the motion. The resolution waives all points of order against consideration of the motion. The Senate amendment shall be considered as read.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 111-694, by Mr. Polis (CO).
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 111-694, by Mr. Polis (CO).

summary.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the Senate amendment to the House amendment to the Senate amendment to the bill (H.R. 3082) making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2010.

bill.title: Providing for consideration of the Senate amendment to the House amendment to the Senate amendment to the bill (H.R. 3082) making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2010, and for other purposes.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
